TextEquiv.Unicode: but that he might declare the thing as
it is indeede so plainely, that it might
easily bee understoode, hee addeth more
over this saying: And to clense us from
al our unrighteousnesse. Loe, heere hee
saith againe from all unrighteousnes,
And for because some caviller might
peradveture, make this obiection and
say. This kinde of docrine maketh
men sluggish and slow to amendment.
For men under the pretence of Gods
grace will not cease to sinne : therfore
John in his 2. chap, auntwereth their
obiection and saith: Babes, these things
write I to you that yee sinne not: and
ifanie man sinne, we have an advocate
with the father lesus Christ the righ
teous. And he is the attonemet for our
sins: and not for our sins onely, but also
for the sinnes of al the worlde. Wher
fore it is alluredly true, that by the
death of Christ all sinnes are forgiven
them that believe.
Moreover, the Lord alone forgiveth
sins. For it is the glorie of God alone
to forgive sinnes, and of unrighteous,
to make men righteous. Therefore,
whereas men are said to forgive sins,
that is to be understood of their mini
sterie, and not of their poler. The mi
nister pronounceth to the people, that
for Christ his sake their sinnes are for
given : and in so saying hee deceyueth
them not: For God in deede forgi
veth the sins of them that beleeverac
cording to that saying: whose sinnes
so we reade not that ye Apostles heard
yee forgive, they are forgiven them
And this is done so often as the worde
of the Gospel is preached, so that there
be no neede to faine that auricular con
fession and private absolution at the
priests hand is necessarie for the re
mission of sinnes. For as auricular
confession was not in use among the
saints before the comming of Christ,

but that he might declare the thing as it is indeede so plainely, that it might easily bee understoode, hee addeth more over this saying: And to clense us from al our unrighteousnesse. Loe, heere hee saith againe from all unrighteousnes, And for because some caviller might peradveture, make this obiection and say. This kinde of docrine maketh men sluggish and slow to amendment. For men under the pretence of Gods grace will not cease to sinne : therfore John in his 2. chap, auntwereth their obiection and saith: Babes, these things write I to you that yee sinne not: and ifanie man sinne, we have an advocate with the father lesus Christ the righ teous. And he is the attonemet for our sins: and not for our sins onely, but also for the sinnes of al the worlde. Wher fore it is alluredly true, that by the death of Christ all sinnes are forgiven them that believe. Moreover, the Lord alone forgiveth sins. For it is the glorie of God alone to forgive sinnes, and of unrighteous, to make men righteous. Therefore, whereas men are said to forgive sins, that is to be understood of their mini sterie, and not of their poler. The mi nister pronounceth to the people, that for Christ his sake their sinnes are for given : and in so saying hee deceyueth them not: For God in deede forgi veth the sins of them that beleeverac cording to that saying: whose sinnes so we reade not that ye Apostles heard yee forgive, they are forgiven them And this is done so often as the worde of the Gospel is preached, so that there be no neede to faine that auricular con fession and private absolution at the priests hand is necessarie for the re mission of sinnes. For as auricular confession was not in use among the saints before the comming of Christ,
private confession, or used privafe ab
solution in the Church of Christ. It
is enough for us to confesse our sinnes
to God, who because hee seeth our
heartes, ought therefore most rightly
to heare our confessiss. It is enough if
wee, as S. James teacheth us, do one
to another betwirt our selves confesso
our faultes and offences, and so after
pardon asked, returne into mutuall
favour againe. It is enough for us to
heare the Gospel, promising ye forgive
nesse of our sinnes through Christ, if
wee believe. Let us therefore believe
the forgivenesse of sinnes, and praye to
the Lord that he wil vouchsafe to give
and increase in us this same beleefe,
These things were of olde and in the
Primitive Church effectuall e nough
to obtaine pardon and full remission of
sinnes: & as they were, so are they un
doubtedly at this day sufficient too,
Furthermore, the Lord doth so par
don our sinnes, not that they shoulde
not be any more in us, nor leave their
reliques behind them as a sting in our
flesh, but that they should not be im
puted to us to our damnation. Concu
piscence sticketh fast, and sheweth it
selfe in our flesh, striving still with the
good spirite of god, even in the holie
ones so long as life lasteth on this
earth. Here therefore wee have neede
of long waching and much fasting, to
draw from the flesh the nourishmet of
evil, & often praiers to call to God for
ayde, that wee bee not overcome of the
evill. And if any man shal hap to faile
for feeblenes, and be subdued of temp
tation, let him not yeeld himself by ly
ing still, to be caught in the divels net,
let him rise up agayne by repentance,
and runne to Christ, beleeving, that by
the death of Christ this fall of his shal
be forgiven him. Aud so often shall
he have recourse to him as hee shall be

private confession, or used privafe ab solution in the Church of Christ. It is enough for us to confesse our sinnes to God, who because hee seeth our heartes, ought therefore most rightly to heare our confessiss. It is enough if wee, as S. James teacheth us, do one to another betwirt our selves confesso our faultes and offences, and so after pardon asked, returne into mutuall favour againe. It is enough for us to heare the Gospel, promising ye forgive nesse of our sinnes through Christ, if wee believe. Let us therefore believe the forgivenesse of sinnes, and praye to the Lord that he wil vouchsafe to give and increase in us this same beleefe, These things were of olde and in the Primitive Church effectuall e nough to obtaine pardon and full remission of sinnes: & as they were, so are they un doubtedly at this day sufficient too, Furthermore, the Lord doth so par don our sinnes, not that they shoulde not be any more in us, nor leave their reliques behind them as a sting in our flesh, but that they should not be im puted to us to our damnation. Concu piscence sticketh fast, and sheweth it selfe in our flesh, striving still with the good spirite of god, even in the holie ones so long as life lasteth on this earth. Here therefore wee have neede of long waching and much fasting, to draw from the flesh the nourishmet of evil, & often praiers to call to God for ayde, that wee bee not overcome of the evill. And if any man shal hap to faile for feeblenes, and be subdued of temp tation, let him not yeeld himself by ly ing still, to be caught in the divels net, let him rise up agayne by repentance, and runne to Christ, beleeving, that by the death of Christ this fall of his shal be forgiven him. Aud so often shall he have recourse to him as hee shall be
